w:r.w:t: The Cambridge IGCSE Economics syllabus develops an understanding of economic theory, terminology and principles. Learners study the economics of different countries and how these interrelate. They also learn to work with simple economics data and to use the tools of economic analysis. Learners apply understanding of economics to current economic issues.Â
The learning objectives are to provide a basic understanding of the following:
An understanding of the Basic Economic Problem

finite resources and unlimited wants; economic and free goods; definitions of the factors of production and their rewards; mobility of the factors of production; quantity and quality of the factors of production; definition of opportunity cost; the influence of opportunity cost on decision making; definition of PPC; points under, on and beyond a PPC; movements along a PPC; shifts in a PPC.
Application and analysis of the role of markets in allocating scarce resources

definition of demand; price and demand; individual and market demand; conditions of demand; definition of supply; price and supply; individual and market supply; conditions of supply; the market system; key resources allocation decisions; introduction to the price mechanism; definition of market economic system; advantages and disadvantages of the market economic system; definition of market failure; causes and consequences of market failure; market equilibrium and disequilibrium; causes and consequences of price changes; definition of PED and PES; calculation of PED and PES; determinants of PED and PES; significance of PED and PES; PED and total spending on a product/revenue.
Application and analysis of the role of markets in allocating scarce resources

definition of market failure; causes and consequences of market failure; market equilibrium and disequilibrium; causes and consequences of price changes; definition of PES; calculation of PES; determinants of PES; significance of PES.
Application and analysis of the role of microeconomic decision makers

influences on spending, saving and borrowing; factors affecting an individualâs choice of occupation; wage determination; reasons for differences in earnings; division of labour/specialization; definition of a trade union; the role of trade unions in the economy; the advantages and disadvantages of trade union activity; classification of firms; small firms; causes and forms of the growth of firms; mergers; economies and diseconomies of scale; demand for factors of production; labour-intensive and capital-intensive production; production and productivity; definition and calculation of costs of production; definition and calculation of revenue; objectives of firms; competitive and monopoly markets.
Analyzing the aims of the government and understanding its role in the implementation of the macroeconomic policies-
the macroeconomic aims of government; possible conflicts between

macroeconomic aims; definition of the budget; reasons for government spending; reasons for taxation; classification and principles of taxation; impact of taxation; definition of fiscal policy; fiscal policy measures; effects of fiscal policy on government macroeconomic aims.
Cambridge IGCSE Economics Student's Book Second edition (Cambridge International IGCSE)
Cambridge IGCSE Economics Workbook (Cambridge International IGCSE)
always be respectful and courteous to their teachers and peers
refrain from inappropriate, offensive, disruptive, demeaning or threatening comments
ensure that they do not facilitate any misrepresentation of identity
observe the decorum of the classroom by being appropriately dressed
be prepared for the lesson with all the learning material as required
inform the teacher in advance in case of absenteeism
work on synchronous or asynchronous work as assigned
work on all assignments and assessments with the level of academic integrity expected by the school
Class will start and end promptly at the scheduled times. Class participants are responsible for all material covered in the book
discussed or presented in class either through lecture, activities or guest speakers. Lectures will cover concepts presented in the book and applications discussed in class.

Class participants are expected to maintain a high level of academic honesty and interaction. Cheating or plagiarism will be dealt with severely. ACADEMIC HONESTY IS A REQUIREMENT FOR PASSING THIS COURSE.

Courteous conduct âcontributesâ to class while discourteous conduct detracts from it. Courteous conduct includes turning off laptops before class, not eating in class, not leaving the classroom during class sessions unnecessarily, not âconversingâ during class, making positive contributions to class sessions, and showing respect for others.
Assignments/Projects: If a student is not able to come to class on a day an assignment is due, an emailed assignmentÂ
to the beginning of class will be accepted, with a hard copy delivered to me upon your return to school.
LATE SUBMISSION WILL NOT BE ACCEPTED.
Practice â homework and reviewing content must be done before coming to class.
Notebooks â note-taking: Use your notebook to copy examples, take notes and key information.
Become familiar with the difficulty and style of IGCSE past paper questions.

Late / make up assignment policy: 10% will be deducted from the grade of any work submitted after the due date.Â Work submitted substantially late will have a percentage deducted in accordance with the period of delay.Â If a student is absent, the assignment must be turned in on the first day back to receive full credit. The idea behind this is that students are responsible to check with their teacher to make up missed work.
Tardiness: Be on time for class. All delays or absences will be noted.

Academic honesty: Have in mind that plagiarism will lead to serious consequences. Distinguish between correct paraphrasing, direct quotation, and citation formats. Any notebooks or homework that looks too similar will also face serious penalties.
Respect: Respect each otherâs voice. Listen to each other.
Completion of 80% of all the assignments.
Scoring at least 50% on revision and main tests.
Active participation in class and empathy towards fellow participants.
Assessment type or category can be specific to the subject
(to be taken as the average of last three years grade thresholds)
